articles.headline: Inquiry Into Foreign Bribes at Biomet Hangs Over $13 Billion Merger
articles.snippet: An agreement to sell Biomet to Zimmer Holdings for $13.35 billion may be complicated by reports that Biomet helped bribe officials in Mexico and Brazil.
articles.abstract: An agreement to sell Biomet to Zimmer Holdings for $13.35 billion may be complicated by reports that Biomet helped bribe officials in Mexico and Brazil.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the skyscrapers of Wall Street to the factories of northern Indiana, cheers rang out for one of the biggest mergers of the year. For $13.35 billion, Goldman Sachs and a group of giant private equity firms agreed in April to sell one Indiana medical device maker to another.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: F.B.I. Searches Doral Financial’s Offices in Puerto Rico
articles.snippet: The offices of Doral Financial in San Juan, Puerto Rico, were raided as part of an investigation into the struggling bank.
articles.abstract: The offices of Doral Financial in San Juan, Puerto Rico, were raided as part of an investigation into the struggling bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Tuesday raided the offices of Doral Financial in San Juan, Puerto Rico, as part of an investigation involving the struggling bank.

articles.headline: America’s Christmas Gift Lists, as Seen by Google
articles.snippet: Google, already the repository of our collective fears and hopes, also knows what we are shopping for. Of course it does.
articles.abstract: Google, already the repository of our collective fears and hopes, also knows what we are shopping for. Of course it does.
articles.lead_paragraph: Holiday gifts are supposed to be a surprise until the moment they are unwrapped. But there is a place (other than the North Pole) where these secrets are known: Google.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Derek Willis

articles.headline: Sony, in About-Face, Will Screen ‘The Interview’ in a Small Run
articles.snippet: Sony also left open the door to video-on-demand availability of the movie, either simultaneously with its debut in theaters, or nearly so.
articles.abstract: Sony also left open the door to video-on-demand availability of the movie, either simultaneously with its debut in theaters, or nearly so.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Interview,” the raucous comedy that became the center of a dispute over cybersecurity between the United States and North Korea, will be released in a small number of theaters on Christmas Day after all, Sony Pictures said on Tuesday. The development gave new life to a film that Sony had pulled from distribution last week, after hackers threatened violence against any theater that played it.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Plastic Surgery Tourism Brings Chinese to South Korea
articles.snippet: Cosmetic surgery, pervasive in South Korea, is now the must-do activity for many Chinese visitors.
articles.abstract: Cosmetic surgery, pervasive in South Korea, is now the must-do activity for many Chinese visitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Liu Liping and two college friends recently toured Seoul on a monthlong vacation funded in part by their parents. They saw the sights. They went shopping.

articles.headline: Cuba’s Zeal for Tight Control Casts a Pall on New Markets
articles.snippet: Raúl Castro’s decision to normalize relations was driven by economic interests, but his government seems intent on opening markets only a crack.
articles.abstract: Raúl Castro’s decision to normalize relations was driven by economic interests, but his government seems intent on opening markets only a crack.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARIEL, Cuba — When Raúl Castro officially opened the new container terminal here on Cuba’s northern coast, he described the project and the special business zone alongside it as “a transcendent project for the national economy.”

articles.headline: At Takata, President Cedes Job to Chief
articles.snippet: Shigehisa Takada, the chairman of the airbag manufacturer and a grandson of its founder, assumed the role of president from Stefan Stocker.
articles.abstract: Shigehisa Takada, the chairman of the airbag manufacturer and a grandson of its founder, assumed the role of president from Stefan Stocker.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Japanese airbag manufacturer at the center of a global recall crisis reshuffled its ranks on Wednesday, removing its president and consolidating control under its chairman, the grandson of the company’s founder.

articles.headline: Uber C.E.O. Charged With Violating South Korea Transport Laws
articles.snippet: Seoul prosecutors indicted Travis Kalanick, the ride booking company’s chief executive, as well as its local unit and car-rental partner, for violating taxi licensing laws.
articles.abstract: Seoul prosecutors indicted Travis Kalanick, the ride booking company’s chief executive, as well as its local unit and car-rental partner, for violating taxi licensing laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In another roadblock to Uber’s global expansion, the authorities in South Korea have indicted Travis Kalanick, the chief executive of the ride-booking company, on charges that Uber violated local licensing laws.
